At 05:34 PM 9/24/02 +0200, Mico Carmelo pa grafo:
>plu karo ami
>mi sio volu poko dice de u evolve de plura
>ge-face lingua, e per u-ci analizi logi qo-ka
>in Glosa na habe plura elementa qi es veri akme
>de neo e ge-evolve lingua. 
*Karo Mico e Plu Hetero Glosa-pe,
   Poli-ra acide intra mi vita, e mi pa volu enkore grafo epi u-ci lista.
Sed, Mico grama pa kausa mi te akti id nu.  Plu previo tri seti-mana, mi du
habe libe-tem, e pro bi ma setimana, mi pote ergo pro u developo de Glosa -
pre mi ki versi ad u feru-via, te itera 
ergo iso u treno alexi-pe.
   
>Kron pe face lingua
>qi ne es natura lingua, kosa mo a qi pe puta es
>ke u-ci lingua debi es maxi facili posibili...e
>u-ci koncepa es fo importa, ka in plura natura
>lingua il es plura elementa qi ne es nece pro 
>korekti logi u frasi. U exempla mo in u-ci kampu
>es u lingua qi gene nima Volapük, e qi es fo paleo
>lingua ....in "ge-face lingua landa",
*  Poli anua pa pasa ex u tem de Volapuk ad u tem in qi Ron Clark pa
re-proto un Interglossa ergo, iso Glosa.  Na habe nuli surprise te detekti
poli simpli-ra, kron na compara plu-ci lingua.
   Ron pa dice, "Intra Glosa, nuli verbi muta pro u buta de gramatika."
So, an elimina holo plu morfo-inflekti, qi na detekti intra u latu skope de
natura lingua. 
   Plus, an dice, "Ali verbi pote, ko logika, funktio iso ali mero_
de_dice."  U prima dice-ra concerne plu inflekti intra mo mero de dice, EG
un akti-verbi; alterno u sekunda dice-ra informa na ke u homo concepa iso
nomina-verbi alo akti-verbi, etc, uti u homo ge-grafo forma. 

>   .....   plura kaso : nominativi, akuzativi
>dativi,genitivi....     .....
>U lexi pro exempla :fat (patri)
>                     fati (patri akuz.)
>                     fata (de u patri gen.)
>                     fate  (a patri dat.)
>fat binom in dom  (patri es in domi.)
>givob fate buki    (mi dona a patri u bibli.)
>dom fata binon jönik  (domi de patri es kali.)
>lofob fati  (mi filo u patri.).
*   E plu-ci 'kaso' ne existe intra England-lingua; so, na pote logi ke plu
kaso ne eqa un esentia elementa de lingua.
    Na habe u klari difere: alo na dice ko plu enigma de plu vario kaso;
alo na separa plu verbi, e uti pusi partikla te indika qod acide a plu
ludo-ra intra na frasa.

>Na pote facili vide ke per Glosa na evita plura kaso sed 
>na expresi homo koncepa,...so qo-ka na debi habe komplika 
>elementa qi es plura kaso.
*   Veri so!

>Hetero ge-face lingua, Esperanto ko-co pa uti 
>koncepa de kaso sed solo mo: u kaso akuzativi
>Mi legas la libron. (mi lekto u bibli.)
*   U-ci uti de solo mo kaso intra Esperanto, posi monstro ke id eqa mo
kaso excesi.  Ko-co, Esperanto habe mo centi anua ma eva de Glosa; e u
histori de komunika pa habe mega muta - iso radio e televideo - durante
u-ci tem.

>e u-la elementa fo komplika u doci de u-ci lingua..ka in 
>Esperanto kaso akuzativi habe ko-co signifi de tem, e de 
>kine qi plura homi qi dice latino plu lingua ne pote 
>facili logi......
*   U qestio de u simpli 'akusativi' versio de u nomina-verbi, ne habe
signifi intra Glosa, ka singu funktio forma de mo ideo nomina-verbi habe u
homo apare.  Pre nu, plu-pe pa imagina ke mu nece habe difere morfo forma
pro plu difere funktio de mo concepa.
    Mi ne logi u signifi de tu stresi ke un akti gene ge-asocia ko u
nomina-verbi.  Per loka un akti-verbi, akti-verbi grega, alo akti-verbi
major-grupa, intra u centra loka de u frasa, na ski plu akti de plu vario
ra intra u frasa.  Per detekti plu nomina-verbi marka - "u", "plu" alo mu
eqa-ra - na loka plu nomina-verbi; e plu-ci marka .. iso plu pali de u
pedi-bola ludo .. indika a na u loka de un akti-verbi grega - inter plu bi
marka-pali. 
    Nece, ko na uti de Glosa, singu frasa ne habe simpli struktura: e, ko
mi previo frasa, tu pote detekti u frasa; qi ne habe solo mo akti grega e
bi ra (Subjekti-Akti-Objekti); id apare de habe poli 'marka-pali' seqe un
akti-verbi.  Sed, per un uti de plu punkta-marka, plu-pe pote duce u
struktura de id.  Anti-co, u-ci faktu posi monstra u major problema ko
Glosa: te grafo boni ge-forma Glosa, uno-pe nece habe u boni logi de plu
regula de sintaxi.  Plu-ci regula [de sintaxi] ne gene ge-sko intra plu
sko-do nu-di.  So, na nece spe ke plu-pe lekto plu boni ge-grafo bibli, te
gania plu regula de lingua uti. 
    Mi kredi ke futura genera de stude-pe fu gene plu-ci regula ex mu
doci-pe.  Sed, nu, plu pasivi media de radio e televideo milita anti u-ci.
Ko u procesa de simplifi lingua, na gene facili ko eduka, sed na lose u
generali abili de produce klari expresi.  Plu-pe gania solo u hemi mero de
u histori: mu gania lekto-sko, sed nuli  
grafo-sko.

> Hetero elementa qi na ne nece pro logi es  u 
>sufixi de infinitivum qi exempla
>hetero ge-face lingua oti sed Glosa korekte ne habe. 
>Exempla Esperanto habe -i  lavi, diri, uzi,Volapük habe 
>-ön, lemön,pükön,lofön, 
>Ido habe -ar, parolar, vidar, skribar, solo 
>Novial 1930 pa logi u-ci koncepa e in Novial 1930 na ne 
>habe sufixi pro indika u infinitivum....
>sed hetero lingua iso Occidental pa uti id...
>e Interlingua habe tri sufixi pro indika u 
>infinitivum...dicer,finir,voler,amar, e u-la es efekti 
>no-nece.
*  Mi ne pa ski ke u simpli forma de un akti-verbi pa habe, intra plu
hetero lingua, plu tali morfo forma.
   Kron mi grafo uti Glosa, plura tem mi este u nece - pro klari expresi -
de uti u partikla te indika mi uti de un akti-verbi sine subjekti alo
objekti.  E so, intra u-ci previo frasa mi monstra bi de plu-ci uti: ~de~ e
~te~. 
  DE - [of, about, (to)]
  TE - [in order to]
e.g. ~de uti~ = "of using" alo "(to) use"
     ~te indika~ = "in order to indicate" alo "to indicate"
   Ex u-ci, mi pote dice ke mi uto tri forma de un 'no-finiti' akti-verbi:
kursi, de kursi, te kursi.
  1. Mi hedo kursi.  [I like to run.]; [I like running.]
  2. An habe nece de kursi, ka u tosto horo. 
        [He had need of running, because of the late hour.];
        [He needed to run, because ... ] 
      ALTERNO
     An pa nece kursi.  [He needed to run.]
  3. Te kursi ad an ergo-lo, an pa loka epi an, plu latex-sola pedi-ve.
[In order to run to work, he put on ... ];
        [To run to work, he put on ... ]

>  U plurali de plu lexi ne es nece pro logi u 
>koncepa de frazi...ko-co natura lingua iso pro exempla 
>indonesian e kwetchua ne uti sufixi pro indika plurali, 
>sed mu indikas plurali solo kron id es absoluti nece per 
>ante-lexi..iso in Glosa...Panto-pe ski ke na habe bi oku, 
>bi poda, bi kiro, bi pedi...e ke na nece bi poda-te, bi 
>pedi-te....et cetera...sed maxi mero de ge-face lingua uti 
>u morfo pro indika plurali...
>pro mea ab verbo ad lexi na ne nece sufixi, sed kontextu 
>de frazi dic a na korekti sensu...
*  Veri, kron uti Glosa, na ne nece uti u plurali partikla pro sungu uti.
   Anti-co, pro logika, na monstra u difere inter:-
      An pote moti solo mo poda.        E
      Bi an plu poda pa moti fo rapidi.

   E na pote logi u difere inter:-
      Undu u poda: tem te leve-auto.      E
      Mi vo vide plu pedi epi u suela.

>u eko  the living
>u kanta  the singing
*  U-ci uti eqa un abstrakti, objektivi forma de un koncepa.
   Id funktio iso u nomina-verbi, intra u sintaxi de u frasa.

>sed mi pote dic  "u ju-fe kanta ...."      ........ (A)
>alo "u kanta de ju-fe pa es fo kali..."    ........ (B)
*   Mi kredi, ke intra (A) tu dona stresi ad u ju-fe; tem, intra (B), tu
dona u stresi ad u kanta.

>Na debi fo boni ski plu karakteri boni de na lingua...pro 
>indika mi puta a hetero homi ke nu-di na nece internatio 
>lingua qi es iso-tem facili pro singu homi, e veri 
>internatio. Plu karo saluta Mico Carmelo ab Mainz.        
>--------------------------------------------------
*   Mi habe un este ke u-ci tri-linea frasa ne habe sufici struktura; e,
plu mero nece habe ma boni defini-ra.  Anti-co, tu sentimenta es exakti.
    Mi proba de u frasa es u-ci: kron tu rola plu verbi intra tu buka, qe,
mu soni dona un este de u semani; e seqe, habe akusti qod tu pa dice, e,
u-ci tem, tu rola plu verbi intra tu menta, qe, mu klari dona u histori; qi
tu tende?  Si alo responde eqa 'no,' tu debi reforma u holo frasa.

Mi pa gene hedo ex lekto tu ergo,
saluta, 

Robin Gaskell

-(doci-pe) vi es ka vi pa desira es ci, ka iso na pa dice

idio kron na psiko ne es in karcera de materia soma id 
viagia fo tako te detekti mode te 
sati id desira. Vi pote puta ke kron  pro exempla vi 
sopo..freqe vi sonia plura kosa  qi 
norma vi ne pote habe in reali, e u-la  acide ka tem sonia 
vi psiko ne es ge-liga a vi soma 
e so id viagia te sati plura kosa. Idio tem  po-morta 
psiko es fo libe...e ne pluso debi 
retroveni a soma, so id ski ke nu pote viagia ali-lo id 
volu.Plura arkeo demo pa habe 
u-ci epistemo, pro exempla qo-ka plura demo  pa akti 
pirami iso religio-do.....
-(sko-pe) mi ne ski...efekti id es fo stimula!
-(doci-pe) Egipti exempla e Maja in bi area fo tele alelo 
pa akti pene homo struktura pro religio motiva.
Na ski ke arkeo-tem pa existe mega kontinenta inter Europa 
e Amerika di qi nima pa es 
Atlantis, e po u-la kontinenta pa dispare...u-la es mega 
misteri de histori, sed na debi dic 
ke u-la efekti pa acide retro plura anua. Plu-la demo  pa 
komunika alelo ka inter mu pa 
existe u-la kontinenta, e posi mu pa habe mega teknologi 
ski. Sed plu-la kultura pa fini
  e u fini de plu-la kultura es pro u skience-pe de geo fo 
misteria. 
-(sko-pe) mi ne pote kredi ke na pote es qod vi dic...
-(doci-pe) qe tu es tu plu vesti?...nu-di tu habe plu-la 
vesti e fu-di tu fu habe neo vesti, so tu lase
tu vesti e tu ne es plu vesti qi tu habe epi tu soma....
-(sko-pe) u-la es veri...
-(doci-pe) qe tu es tu soma?...tem u-ci bio tu habe u-la 
soma, sed tem tu fu-bio tu fu habe hetero 
soma...so tu ne es tu soma.....qe tu es tu plu desira? 
plura desira gene sati e ne pluso 
existe sed neo plu desira veni te gene sati...so tu ne es 
tu plu desira....so qo tu efekti es?
imagina ke tu ne es ni tu vesti, ni tu soma, ni tu 
desira....qo tu pote es?
-(sko-pe) mi pote akti u-la...mi volu filo, mi volu u kali 
mi volu eko...eko,filo,kali....
-(doci-pe) tu boni pa dice...tri valu : eko, filo, kali
qo es eko: eko volu dice:mi volu eko, mi volu habe bio, e 
in u-ci bio mi volu gene filo 
alo mi sio volu filo uno-pe, mi volu audi alo vide u kali, 
e qo es u kali? kali flori es kali
u kali de natura, u kali de harmoni muzika, u kali de 
aglao onto....u kali u bio u filo....
e qe u sexu ne es morfo te expresi u filo ,
plura societa puta ke u sexu es no-boni alo no-puri kosa, 
sed si na reflekti na pote logi ke
  u sexu in ali morfo id es ge-expresi es filo-ru. So, mi 
desira sexu, mi habe in mi plura 
sexu desira qi mi ne pote sati...u societa skema freqe ne 
lase u libe te expresi u veri sexu 
desira e na debi es hipokriti...ko-co si inter na e na 
fe-sponsa nuli-ra existe na dice...ja u-la 
es veri sed qe mi pote dice mi lase u-ci gina te habe neo 
gina e plu filia e u lega seqe.....
so mi resta ci-mode ka si mi sio volu kambio u-la sio es 
fo risko pro mi. Ci-mode na habe 
in na psiko plura no-ge-expresi desira qi atende u morta e 
u neo bio te veni ex de na psiko,
  qi longi-tem pa tena mu.
-(sko-pe) so soma volu dice : idea plus libido plus 
materia plus morfo?
-(doci-pe) u-la es exakti, kron na eko in karcera na freqe 
puta...qe mi fu akti kron mi fu es libe?
inter-tem na stru in na psiko na fu-soma qi fu habe bio in 
fu-bio, e u-ci explika ka vi es
ci epi u-ci planeta.Qe vi pa habe ci, pro exempla,
pedio-tem?ne, absoluti ne...vi tako pa habe norma e 
ge-kresce soma, vi ne pa debi 
atende iso epi geo pedio-tem, adolesce-tem te habe  akti 
soma te komence expresi vi 
desira,ci vi pa habe vi soma sine ki in ventra de gina e 
 la resta pro nona meno ci vi pa 
habe tako vi neo soma qi vi longi-tem pa desira.E vi fu 
eko ci pro holo tem, ka ci u morta
  ne existe, so vi ne pote morta, e vi pote expresi vi 
plura  desira minus fini pro panto-tem 
e vi soma nuli-tem pote ski u paleo-tem alo gene no-kali 
 pro paleo-tem iso epi geo topo 
panto geronto-pe es no-kali e geronto-tem es bio-tem in qi 
societa e plu parenta no-memo
  vi...u societa epi geo pre kron vi es juve exploita vi, 
po kron vi es geronto-pe bali vi iso rude
  ka vi ne pluso es funktio pro u-la societa e pro plu-la 
valu qi es esentia u valuta, solo u 
valuta, andro epi geo es nuli-ra solo valuta existe pro 
plu-la stupidi andro. Id es no-kredi 
sed qod mi explika a vi es efekti qod acide epi u-la tele 
planeta."

So, plu karo ami, mi spe ke mi pusi mero de noveli de 
skience-fikti pa es stimula
pro vi....ali-mode na kali lingua nece 
literatura!!.......e mi spe ke mi ne pa fatiga vi!
vi karo ami Mico Carmelo Ranibakt ab Mainz

mi konsidera Italia iso u maxi mali stato in qi
u andro pote eko, mi ko-co ne akorda ko

logi u-la demo e nu ke mi eko in Deutsch-landa
mi es fo hedo eko ci...e mi volu no-memo Italia
pro holo mi resta bio epi geo.
Ali-mode mi pa nati in Italia e po mi pa veni a
Deutsch-landa te eko pro holo tem
mi ne pa pote detekti ergo in Italia e mi 
koerce debi ki extra-landa e mi pa elekti 
Deutschlanda e mi es hedo de u-la.
Nu in Deutschlanda mi es hedo ....Deutsch-landa
es kali e mi amo id.

Mi familia nima es Miko, iso tu pote facili vide
id es heleni, ka ko-co in Glosa na habe lexi 
eqa "miko" qi volu dice "fungus"
efekti miko-logi (micology) es u stude de plu miko
e mi efekti amo fago plu miko in difere mode
u miko es boni sito ...sed ko-co id pote es toxi!
na debi kura kron na sume u miko in bosko ....
id pote es toxi...e na debi habe u ski te fago id
si na ne habe u epistemo na pote morta per id.
U-la es efekti e u-la pa es mi bio...mi holo tem

plura andro vendo plura falsi epistemo e per 
plu-la epistemo mu eko e mu gania plura valuta.

u-la es solo filosofi teori, qi ne habe nuli-ra

Plu karo ami
Mi es hedo bali a vi u kapitula mo de u Bhagavad Gita 
ge-translati in Glosa ex mi,
mi nu akti u translati de u-ci bibli qi es fo importa pro 
orienta religio
e qi tena plura fo importa e filosofi koncepa qi pote 
explika plura
mali de na bio e de na societa. Mi es sura ke panto-pe qi 
fu lekto
id pote detekti id fo stimula. Nu mi ergo te translati u 
kapitula bi 
qi es fo stimula pro id plura filosofi valu e id plura 
explika de u bio
pre e po u morta de u materia soma. Mi spe ke id pote es 
stimula 
pro panto-pe e....boni lekto! 
               BHAGAVAD GITA

  

Kapitula mo.   U observa plu arme in batalia kampu de
                         Kuruksetra.


1.    Dhritarastra pa dic : Oh Sanjaja! Qo-ra pa akti mi 
plu fili
        e plu fili de Pandu te inkontra alelo in u iti-lo 
de Kuruksetra
        te lukta.

2.   Sanjaja pa dic : oh an-regi! po an pa mira u arme  qi 
gene
        uni ex plu fili de Pandu, an-regi Durjodhana pa 
veni ad se
        doci-pe e an pa komence dice plu seqe lexi :

3.   Oh mi doci-pe! Il es ci u mega arme de plu fili de 
Pandu, 
        ge-ordina tekno-mode ex tu intelige sko-pe, u fili 
de Drupada.

4.   Ci in u-ci arme il es poli hero sagita-pe, qi es 
eqivalu in u lukta
        a Bhima e Arjuna, e il es mega milita-pe iso 
Jujudhana, Virata
        e Drupada.

5.   Il es ko-co poli mega hero e forti milita-pe, iso : 
Dhristaketu, 
       Cekitana, Kasiraja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja e Saibja.

6.   Il es u magnifi Judhamanju, u fo dina Uttamanja, u 
fili de Subhadra
       e plu fili de Draupadi. Plu-ci milita-pe es mega 
lukta-pe. 

7.   O u maxi boni de plu brahmana! Pro tu info, lase mi 
dice a tu de
        plu kefa-pe qi es fo tekno te duce mi milita dina.

8.   Il es plu homi iso : tu auto, iso Bhisma, Karna, 
Kripa, Asvattama,
       Vikarna e u fili de Somadatta ge-nima Bhurisrava, 
qi pa vikto holo tem
       in batalia.

9.   Il es poli hetero hero qi es prepara te dona u bio 
pro mi. Panto-pe posesi
       difere klasi de arma e ko-co habe u experi de 
milita skience.

10. Na dina es fo mega e na ko-co gene alexi ex u patri 
patri de Bhisma, tem
       ke u dina de plu Pandava qi kura gene alexi ex 
Bhima es ge-limita.

11. Nu panto-pe debi dona se tena a patri patri Bhisma e 
resta in se lukta-lo intra
        de u ordina de arme.

12. So Bhisma, u mega e valu an-regi de u dinasti Kuru, u 
patri patri de plu 
        milita-pe, pa fla se konka ko mega fono, iso u 
rugi de leo e an sti hedo
        in Durjodhana.

13. Po-co panto konka pa fono, plu cimbali, plu gong, plu 
trompeta plu timpani
        e plu bucina e u ge-uni fono pa feno u mega fono 
de tempestu.

14. In u anti-latu, Krishna e Arjuna, in mu kriso vagona 
ge-trakto ex tetra albi equs,
        pa fla mu plu celestia konka.

15. So u Kirio Krishna pa fla an konka ge-nima 
Panchajanja, Arjuna pa fla u-an,
        de qi u nima pa es Devadatta, e Bhima pa fla an 
konka ge-nima Paundra.

16. U an-regi Judhisthira, u fili de Kunti pa fla se 
konka, u Anantavijaja e Nakula
        e Sahadeva pa fla Sughosa e Manipuspaka.

17. O an-regi! u mega sagita-pe, u an-regi de Kasi, u mega 
milita-pe Sikhandi,
        Dhristadjumna, Virata e u no-ge-vikto Satjaki.

18. Drupada, plu fili de Draupadi e plu hetero homi iso u 
fili de Subhadra, ko dina
        braki e panto plu-la pa fla mu konka.

19. U fono de plu-ci difere konka pa es tumultu e id pa 
resoni dia geo e urani e
        pa lacera plu kardia de plu Kauravas.

20. O an-regi! Nu Arjuna u fili de Pandu qi pa es ge-sedi 
in an vagona e de qi
        insigni pa fero u sema de Hanumana, pa sume an 
arka e

21. pa dice plu-ci lexi a Kirio Krishna: O Kirio sto u 
vagona inter u bi arme ke mi
22  pote vide qo-pe volu lukta e anti qo-pe mi sio debi 
akti u batalia.

23. Lase mi vide plu-la qi pa veni ci te lukta te servi u 
mali an-fili de Dhritarastra.

24. Sanjaja pa dice : O an-regi!, Kirio Krishna, loka u 
vagona inter u bi arme,
        iso Arjuna pa qestio. 

25. Ante de Bhisma, Drona e panto an-regi, Krishna 
(Hrisikesa) u Kirio pa dice:
        vide tu solo, O Arjuna, ante a panto Kurus qi es 
ci ge-uni.

26. La Arjuna pa vide an plu fratri patri, an plu patri 
patri, an plu doci-pe, an plu 
        fratri matri, an plu an-sibi, an plu fili, an plu 
fili fili e an plu ami.

27. an pa vide plu-la parenta e gina patri e plu hetero 
karo homi qi pa es 
        prepara te lukta in bi arme

28. Arjuna pa dic : Mi karo Krishna si mi vide mi plu ami 
e mi plu parenta qi es
        ci te lukta mi plu membra tremulo e mi stoma gene 
sika.

29. Mi holo soma tremulo e mi plu triko gene orto. Mi arka 
Gandiva kade ab mi
        kiro e mi kuti incende.

30. Mi ne pote resta ci poli-tem, oh Krishna mi vide plu 
mali portento.
31  Mi ne pote vide u logika te cide mi plu parenta in 
batalia. 

32. Mi ne desira ni vikto ni hedo o regi landa O Krishna! 
Qo es u uti de regi landa
        de u hedo o ko-co de u bio O Krishna! 

33. Kausa plu-la kosa, ka na desira regi landa, plu hedo e 
plu fru, nu na es ci 
        prepara te lukta e na renuncia na bio e na plura 
pluto.

34. Plu doci-pe, plu fratri patri, plu fili, plu patri 
patri, plu fratri matri, plu patri gina
        e plu hetero parenta.

35. Mi ne volu cide mu, qi ko-co es prepara te cide, ko-co 
pro u krati de tri kosmo

36. O Krishna qo hedo mi sio pote habe in cide plu fili de 
Dhritarashtra?
        U akti u-la es solo peka.

37. Ka-co, na ne sio debi cide na plu fratri, plu fili de 
Dhritarashtra.
        Qo-mode na pote es hedo po ke na cide na plu 
parenta, O Krishna!

38. Mu gene cecilo ex lafigmo e mu ne pote vide u mali de 
u destru de holo famili,
        id sio es fo boni u ki ab de u-ci peka O Krishna!

40. Per u destru de holo famili, ko-co u panto-tem 
traditio gene destru, e plu mali
        more gene vigi kausa u-la destru

41. e kron plu mali more prevale, plu gina de famili gene 
vitia, e kron plu gina gene
        vitia, plura sociali problema surge.

42. U-la duce u famili e plu membra de famili ad hades, ka 
plu spiritu de plu 
43  pre-parenta ne pluso cepti plu ceremoni ofere de oriza 
e de aqa

44. U demo qi pa destru plu famili traditio fu eko in 
hades pro longi-tem.

45. Na es prepara te akti mega peka, in cide na plu 
parenta qi gene cecilo ex
       lafigmo.

46. Id sio es fo boni pro mi ke plu fili de Dhritarashtra 
fu cide mi per mu arma
        iso-tem ke mi es minus arma.

47. Sanjaja pa dic: po u dice de plu-la lexi Arjuna bali 
an arka e plu sagita e sedi
        epi u vagona ko menta ple de no-hedo.

At 02:41 PM 9/25/02 EDT, Sid Pidd wrote:
>
>
>U domi-aqua ergo-pe pa habe un alti e an pa habe u lati de skapa .
>
*  Hello Sid and all,
   I really wanted to reply to this message ... until I started trying to
get into it.
   Well, I persevered, and know that Sid doesn't like plumbers because they
have palatial houses, charge an excessive amount for their services, often
make a bigger mess than there was before they started, are very scarce, and
the poor householder has no recourse, in law, at least not in the UK.
   But if I was asked to draw a map of the leaky covered pipes in Sid's
flat .. even if my life depended on it .. I would have to pass.

   So, Sid's been at Glosa longer than I have, but the fact that he does
not write user-friendly Glosa, is part of the case against Glosa.

   Well, we don't have a full-scale dictionary , and "plumber" is not
listed, so Sid had to derive a word as best he could: ~domi-aqua ergo-pe~
it aint.  Well, by now, there should have been a set of easily followable
guidelines, for the derivation of neologisms, but there is not.
   So we are left on our wits and with the small Latin dictionary, which,
incidentally, has no listing for plumber.
   However, we know that lead drains were found in Pompeii, so there must
have been lead-workers in ancient Rome.  PLUMBA = lead (Pb).
   So, were Sid provided with derivation guidelines, his plumber might have
come out looking more like ~plumba-ergo-pe~.

>ma-pre,epi infra de kamera tegu, u mi fe-sponsa pa vide u peci de humidi. 
*  I would like a more descriptive use of the language, but Sid's use of
Glosa is within the Open Plan that Ron left us.
   While there are no rules of syntax - published by any authoritative
Glosa Language Committee - and while there is no system of accreditation -
with instruction, correction of assignments, and qualifying examination -
then Sid's usage is as good as the next man's.
   The fact that it makes my head spin trying to make sense of it, cannot
be a criticism of Sid, but of a language that can't decide on a set of
rules for its grammar, and which leaves its usage open to the language
sense of its practitioners.

>'mi du puta ke vil es u tubi fora in tegu-space', fe pa dice.
>so, na pa petitio un ergo-pe visita.
>u an domi du habe sixa kamera epi u suela, bi  multi tri, e3 tri supra mo
poste altero, plu-co es in domi-tegu.
>
*  Thus I will leave Sid's leaky pipes at this point.
   Though I wonder which is more important: to get the vocabulary
absolutely spotless; or to consider deriving a set of "best practice" rules
for the use of syntax in an IAL with Syntax-based Grammar!?

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

Robin wrote, in part:

> The fact that it makes my head spin trying to make sense of it, cannot
> be a criticism of Sid, but of a language that can't decide on a set of
> rules for its grammar, and which leaves its usage open to the language
> sense of its practitioners.

Then, Syd replied, in part:

> as far as
> I can see the method is to find the glosa equivalent of each  english  word,
> put it down in english sentence order but without the grammar markers - not
> at all satisfactory.

Then, Marcel reminded:

> The book "Central Glosa", p. 107, suggests "tubi-pe".  So we have
> tubi-pe also in the Glosa Internet Dictionary,
> http://www.glosa.org/gid/engl.htm .

Actually, every language is a slave to the whims of its users.
The people demand all kinds of contradictory things simultaneously,
which explains the illogic of language, not to mention politics.
If only English-users try Glosa, naturally they import their idioms,
and then it fails as an inter-language for the majority of Europeans;
the goal was to make a simple Lingua Franca for the modern world.

Words like "tubi-pe" are not going to fly, obviously, so the question
is whether to move on to the next step in Glosa's evolution, or just
abandon it altogether. I think there are enough good features in
Hogben's version 1 (Interglossa) and today's version 2 (Glosa) to
suggest that a version 3 would be well worth pursuing. However,
a schism (Ido/Esperanto, Occidental/Interlingua) would be ruinous.

To: <glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Subject: Re: [glosalist] complaints
From: "Jay Bowks" <jjbowks{at}adam{dot}cheshire{dot}net>
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 13:34:27 -0400

From: <Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com>
> abandon it altogether. I think there are enough good features in
> Hogben's version 1 (Interglossa) and today's version 2 (Glosa) to
> suggest that a version 3 would be well worth pursuing. However,
> a schism (Ido/Esperanto, Occidental/Interlingua) would be ruinous.

The question is therefore:
Is Glosa good enough for communicating in?
I would think it is, I've seen is used as such
on this list. It is easy enough to use after some
period of casual study. I wouldn't say that 
Glosa is a schism of Interglossa, nobody
that I know of uses Interglossa, it's dead like
ancient Latin, as an example I wouldn't say
that Spanish is a schism of Latin... Glosa is
alive because it's in use, keep using it and it
remains alive and working, stop using it and
it dies. If there's differing opinions on how to
use Glosa or express things logically in it, well,
there's always the option of going to the 
copyright holder, something not available for
classical Latin, unless we had a spare Roman
in refrigeration that could answer our questions
on usage, but Wendy is still around, thank God
for this and we can always fall back on what 
she feels her language should be like... It's like
Paul Simon's phrase that says:
"Disagreements? Work 'em out."

On whether Interlingua is a schism of Occi,
well I would resoundly say "no". But on this
matter we're going to clash I'm afraid and 
perhaps there's the old song by Dave Mason:
"There ain't no good guys,

a bit scrappy this lot, sorry but
dear robin and all

the plumber was tall [and with broad shoulders.]

we have SVO [O for our purposes]. the key phrase is V as it shows where S and 
O are - it is 'was'. 'was' tells us also the time relation between the 
sentence's time and that of the writing of the sentence - past tense, the 
action/state takes place before the writing. so 'was' is a 
time-relation-phrase [tem-relatio-verba-grega/grupo]. I prefer this 
definition as 'doing-word' and 'akti-verba' are not very apt - nothing is 
being done here. 'was' also tells us the tense and number - economic and 
informative - good for English.
Glosa [from 'Central Glosa'] gives us 'es' for 'to be' and 'pa' for the past 
tense. = 'pa es'
next the object phrase = "alti"
an pa es alti
if we look back in central glosa for 'alti', we get 'high/tall'
the plumber is tall - a long way between his feet and his head, or
the plumber is high - a long way between his feet and the ground - perhaps on 
a ladder.
change of plan:-
the plumber HAD tallness/height 
I think that could work ok
an pa habe alti.

A plumber was a lead[Pb] worker - u plumba-ergo-pe - he is called a plumber 
because he would have used lead 2000 years ago - on the same lines and much 
earlier, a tailor should now be called a boner and flinter!

he was a person, he was working for us - a work-person, he was working on a 
system - a sytem-work-person, it was a water system - a 
water-system-work-person, it was house water - a 
house-water-system-work-person.
each part of the construction helps/modifies/clarifies the following one till 
the final part is the head of the phrase.
glosa has accepted this construction:-
there is one person and start with 'u'. this word introduces our subject 
phrase and at the same time indicates number, it is a numbered phrase/noun 
phrase
u domi-aqa-sistema-ergo-pe
long winded but my dictionary here, central glosa, allows me only about 1000 
words. a dictionary that had Eng-plumber to glosa in it would be much much 
longer.

and he had broad shoulders
'he' is a numbered phrase/NP and is the S.it is a complete phrase and does 
not need "u"
'had' as before
'habe' can be, in G, a V to have/own/posess, a N ownership/posessions, an 
adjective owned, an adverb?
his ownership broadened his shoulders
owner-like, broadly shouldered .....
make it 'the broad shoulders', and it is clear
so
e an pa habe plu lati skapa

I should like to see how other people tackle the sentence and their analyses 
.......
sid

I had written a fantastic reply, then mis-saved it somehow.
   From memory, I went on about the PA being possibly misplaced: it relates

   Also I mentioned that the second PA - relating to his width, could be

   There was reference to the need for a level of conscious thought about

   Sid wanted to point out that ~habe~, by rights, according to Glosa lore,
should just as easily be used as N, Adj and Adv as it is as a V.  I thought
that was pusing it a bit, but agreed there might be non-verb "havingnesses"
where ~habe~ was the right word.
   I pointed out that ~pa es~ was just as easily "did be" as it was "was,"
and that this inflected usage in English clouded the semantics.
   I ended up with 
     ~Mi pa enkontro un alti domi-aqa-sistema-ergo-pe; qi habe plu lati
skapa.~
               Here the PA is firmly with the event, and not with the
person, whom we believe to be still alive.
   In the earlier, obliminated version, I offered Sid a free copy of GLOSA
6000 if he sends his land address.  I actually refer to a print-out of the
ENG->GLO G.I.D. which is more complete than "6000."
   Sid, mate, the offer is still open.
   I did add that for people, being what they are, shorter compounds are
much better than more complete, and more correct, longer ones.  I came out
in favour of 
    ~u plumba-ergo-pe~  over  ~domi-aqa-sistema-ergo-pe~  AND
    ~meso-ra~  if  ~akti-verbi~  won't do, over
                                     ~tem-relatio-verba-grega/grupo~

   People, as I said, being people, will dispense with what they find
cumbersome and unnecessary, and will abbreviate.       
   The  ~meso-ra~ [middle bit]  comes between Subject and Object.

Syd discusses:

> the plumber was tall [and with broad shoulders.]

> we have SVO [O for our purposes].

> so 'was' is a time-relation-phrase [tem-relatio-verba-grega/grupo].

> I should like to see how other people tackle the sentence and their analyses

A long time ago (when trolls were underground) we discussed the ways
different languages have different ideas about what an "adjective"
really is, and about which "parts-of-speech" are really useful;
grammar as taught in most schools is especially confusing about this.
Anyway we must identify in your example sentence that WAS is not
even a real verb, it's just an auxiliary; and TALL is a predicate
adjective, modifying the subject PLUMBER; there is no object,
it is just a subject-predicate kinda thing. Glosa has just two
distinct word-classes, the particles (including BE, HAVE, etc)
and the full words (PLUMBER, HEIGHT, etc).

Most languages do not treat attributive adjectives like English.
We've elevated them to equal status with nouns and verbs, whereas
others usually treat them more like plain nouns or verbs. We must
say "the tall one" where they would say "the tall" or "it talls".
And if a Spanish speaker hears "a man tall" or "a tall man" it is
no obstacle to understanding, but we would get all upset about it.
This is not a problem in those interlanguages that permit either
noun-adjective or adj-noun word order within the noun phrase;
both are statistically equally common among world languages,
and so it seems to me that both should be permitted in Glosa.

I want to avoid the vocabulary question for now, so will just
say "plomero" without further explanation. A definite article
is also needed, so I'll pick "le" for the nonce. For the
concept of height, I guess it has to be something like "alta".
Then we'd get approximately: "Le plomero habe alta", avoiding
the English "predicate adjective" construction. Adding the
shoulders is then straightforward ... Of course "un alta plomero"
or "un plomero alta" could mean several different things, but
that's just the way adjectives work in the real world.

also some Bahá'i and Bible texts on www.glosa.org .  And I think, that
is good:  People can see, that Glosa is valid to express their
feelings, opinions and beliefs, as fas as we try to offer a wealthy
and balanced mixture of Glosa texts.  If one does not like the meaning
of a text, he can easily click to another -- on a website.  But on a
mailing list it is different.

So please do not misuse Glosalist, a linguistic discussion forum, for
making propaganda for one particular religion.  Please do not attack
other religions and do not offend their believers.

From: Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>
Date: Sun, 03 Nov 2002 00:38:02 +1100

At 01:34 PM 10/19/02 -0400, Jay Bowks wrote:
>From: <Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com>
>> abandon it altogether. I think there are enough good features in
>> Hogben's version 1 (Interglossa) and today's version 2 (Glosa) to
>> suggest that a version 3 would be well worth pursuing. However,
>> a schism (Ido/Esperanto, Occidental/Interlingua) would be ruinous.
>
>[Jay] The question is therefore:
>Is Glosa good enough for communicating in?
>I would think it is, I've seen is used as such
>on this list. It is easy enough to use after some
>period of casual study. I wouldn't say that 
>Glosa is a schism of Interglossa, nobody
>that I know of uses Interglossa,   .....
*  Mi Plu Karo Amika,
   I write in English to be quick; I should work harder to do it in Glosa.
   I think that you have misunderstood Charles' intention.
   As I remember the discussion with Charles on the idea of 'perfecting'
Glosa by revising it to a much better version - probably with a different
name - refers to a language to which he has given the working title of,
"Glosa 3."
   So, I interpret Charles' comments, about a possible schism, as being a
schism between Glosa 2 (normal Clark/Ashby Glosa) and Glosa 3 (an ammended
Glosa derivative, as yet to be specified or formed).
   I think this is what Charles implied.
   I am almost certain that he was not suggesting anyone hark back to Glosa
1 (Hogben's Interglossa), and nor was he seeing Glosa 2 (C/A Glosa) as the
improved breakaway.

   This whole Glosa 1 - 3 nomenclature worries me, because to project Glosa
(1992 Version) backwards to dub Interglossa (Hogben, 1943) as _Glosa 1_ is
historical nonsense.  A number of members of Conlang persisted in calling
Glosa "Glossa".  And for people who are pedantic on spellings, I found such
behaviour perverse.
   If anyone must talk about an as yet unformed derivative of current
Glosa, I would suggest that they gave it, the concept, a specific name such
as "N-M Glosa", for 'New Millenium Glosa.'

   And for sure, if a new criterion set was prepared for a language that
was radically better than, or rather different from, current Glosa, which I
might call "Glosa (1992 Ver.)", then such an initiative from within what
might loosely be called the Glosa Movement, would definitely cause a split
in its ranks.
   As it so happens, If I sat down and thought hard, I might come up with a
slightly varied criterion list for Glosa, But I would not push such
possible changes as an agenda: instead, I would use some of the new ideas
in my Glosa writing, in the thought that if they had value, they might
catch on.




>   it's dead like
>ancient Latin, as an example I wouldn't say
>that Spanish is a schism of Latin... Glosa is
>alive because it's in use, keep using it and it
>remains alive and working, stop using it and
>it dies.
*  One of my worries is this keeping Glosa alive by using it.
   I, for one, am not doing enough of it.
   Sid is definitely doing his bit.  Though he and I might differ on points
of usage, our differences are more like differences over English language
usage, than the cause of splitting Glosa into two versions.
   But many more of the Glosa Group should be writing using it.
   Wendy should be receiving an overflow mail of potential items for Plu
Glosa Nota.  We can use the vocabulary as it is: changing spellings is
purely a matter of editing.  The thingwhich takes much more effort is to
get our syntax right.  and even before the lexicon is set inconcrete, we
can start practising word order and Glosa 
constructions.
   Only when we have a reasonably consistent usage of Glosa can we say the
language lives.  I have been caught up, lately, in trying to do something
about the present Australian drought - the country is drier than at any
time since weather records began.
   --> I should compile my lexicon of Glosa words that are drought related,
possibly adding a few neologisms in the process, and then should tell the
yarn in Glosa for PGN readers.

   What stories do other Glosa-pe have running through your heads, at
present: tell the stories in Glosa .. enrich the language by "testing" it
in areas where it may not have been used before.

>   If there's differing opinions on how to
>use Glosa or express things logically in it, well,
>there's always the option of going to the 
>copyright holder, something not available for
>classical Latin, unless we had a spare Roman
>in refrigeration that could answer our questions
>on usage, but Wendy is still around, thank God
>for this and we can always fall back on what 
>she feels her language should be like... 
*  As I was saying, it is a matter of submitting our Glosa usage to Wendy -
preferably in PGN usable articles - rather than our waiting for her to keep
producing example of good Glosa.  Without feeback, we will never know ifwe
are using the language acceptably, or not.
   And, for me, acceptable usage has occurred when most Glosa-pe understand
the writer's intention, and can say they know what he means.

   So, that means Glosa is a language of empathy: people should have a
mental picture of the listener/reader in front of them, when they speak 

It's like
>Paul Simon's phrase that says:
>"Disagreements? Work 'em out."
>
>On whether Interlingua is a schism of Occi,
>well I would resoundly say "no". But on this
>matter we're going to clash I'm afraid and 
>perhaps there's the old song by Dave Mason:
>"There ain't no good guys,
>There ain't no bad guys,
>There's only you and me,
>And we just disagree."
>
>
>Since,
>Jay B.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] How Many Glosas?
From: N0PSB{at}aol{dot}com
Date: Thu, 7 Nov 2002 09:58:51 EST

Dear Colleagues,

I am a new Glosa user, and I am not a linguist or language builder - I have 
far too much trouble writing well in English to consider myself other than an 
imperfect  language user.  As a result, I think I have a different 
perspective on Glosa from some of the discussion on the list.  

For me it does not matter whether Glosa is perfect or fine tuned if no one 
uses it.  We have some discussion on this list in Glosa, we have a newsletter 
from time to time, and not much more.  If I wrote a book in Glosa (or if any 
other member of this list did so), who would buy and read it?  Glosa poorly 
constructed but used is far more relevant than Glosa perfectly constructed 
and unused.  

If I am going to go to the trouble of learning and using a language I want it 
to be stable.  The rules of French grammar or Spanish grammar do not change 
every month - but if Glosa had followed all of the excursions I have seen on 
this list, our change rate would be at least once a month.  If I learn Glosa, 
or Glosa 2, or whatever it is we are using, and the handful of people on the 
list decide that they want to use Glosa 3, or New Millennium, or whatever, 
then we all either have to relearn or we have to accept that we are becoming 
the ever more perfect members of an ever decreasing herd.  That is perhaps a 
fine thing if the objective is perfection of a hobby - it is a horrible thing 
if the intent is to communicate with a larger and larger sphere of people.

Constant change is even more difficult if we intend to ever publish a body of 
literature in Glosa, in my mind an absolute requirement for growth in the 
number of users.  I asked this question earlier, and someone noted that they 
could read something that had been written in Glosa years before.  That is 
the cost of the language being stable - and whether or not you like Wendy 
"owning" the language, that is the very great benefit of it.  If Glosa is 
going to change routinely there is no reason for me, or any other author, to 
write in it - half of the purpose of publishing books and articles is to 
ensure the continuity of knowledge.  If 10 years from now people cannot read 
what I have written because Glosa is Glosa 17, we will have missed the point. 
  

I think debate about the future evolution of Glosa is a good thing.  I think 
arguing about how best to express grammatical forms is wonderful.  But I 
wonder why I do not see debate about how best to structure courses in basic 
Glosa, what the content for an equivalent to the 10 lesson Esperanto course 
should be and how to recruit tutors to deliver it, about how to develop and 
encourage more publications in Glosa, about how to recognize Glosa 
proficiency - in short about how to grow the community of users so that we 
will have enough people to make all the inward looking arguments worthwhile 
and significant?

I have proposed a Glosa introductory course for my University's Continuing 
Professional Development and Personnel Enrichment Program (our continuing 
education unit community outreach program).  We may even look at doing it 
online.  So who has a good idea about what I should teach and how to get 
students into the program?

And has anyone ever wondered why we use an emblem that is a marketing and 
logo design nightmare to sell our language?  At least the Esperantists have a 
simple green star ... and an easily recognizable flag ...

Walter

I'm very new to glosa---I like what (little) I know of the langauge,
but a few things occurred to me (unstructured babble commences):

If the goal is to skim internationality from common languages,
surely `helo' is a better greeting than `ave'..?  Ave gets the piss
taken out of it in Asterix IIRC (which I do, a small point, I know)

Artificial language `lojban' dispenses with uppercase letters (a
most elegant move!), and while glosa is targetted at europeans I
presume (who are already aquainted with uppercase and such), that
would be a good change to the language in my humble, uneducated,
opinion.

I agree that major changes are probably undesirable; if any are to be
made, they must be made before the tutorials are written ;-).  Language
does of course change (Marlowe can be great, but he's fucking
impossible to read in any original form without translating
constantly), but yes, I agree the literature of last decade must
remain comprehensible!

The glosa symbol I also thought ridiculous.  How about a red triangle?
It's easy, and it can be asciified thusly: [/\]

The main things that repelled me from esperanto:

1: There were suffixes for: male, unspecified-gender and female.  The
   default form of words was probably male but I was unsure about what
   constituted best practice.
2: There was no list of absolute minimum vocabulary, such as glosa
   mil.  The closest I could find was a vocab list for GCSE
   (high-school-level (16 y/o) exams in Britain).

The main things that attracted me to glosa:

1: A pair of dictionaries in a well-described text-based format so I
   could hack together a basic word-lookup tool.  My esperanto equivalent
   is *much* cruder.
2: It's a piece of piss to read with a dictionary programme; I learnt
   the basics from a big list of translated sentences about `she is going
   to town' etc.  This was much easier than the intellectual effort
   required to read a tutorial.

On a more negative note, I was put off considerably by the connection
to latin.  That word evokes fear in people!  I would suggest replacing
it with "common european word roots" wherever possible!

I never used the esperanto interactive tutorials (OK, so I did, but
not the interactive element); I would welcome friendly glosa intro
material, of course, but for my own learning, I'd rather have my
dictionary-grepper and a translated fairy-tale (If anyone wants to
write/translate fairy tales or similar literature, I'd love it!).

paci, Tom

> I am a new Glosa user, and I am not a linguist or language builder - I have 
> far too much trouble writing well in English to consider myself other than an 
> imperfect  language user.  As a result, I think I have a different 
> perspective on Glosa from some of the discussion on the list.  
> 
> For me it does not matter whether Glosa is perfect or fine tuned if no one 
> uses it.  We have some discussion on this list in Glosa, we have a newsletter 
> from time to time, and not much more.  If I wrote a book in Glosa (or if any 
> other member of this list did so), who would buy and read it?  Glosa poorly 
> constructed but used is far more relevant than Glosa perfectly constructed 
> and unused.  
> 
> If I am going to go to the trouble of learning and using a language I want it 
> to be stable.  The rules of French grammar or Spanish grammar do not change 
> every month - but if Glosa had followed all of the excursions I have seen on 
> this list, our change rate would be at least once a month.  If I learn Glosa, 
> or Glosa 2, or whatever it is we are using, and the handful of people on the 
> list decide that they want to use Glosa 3, or New Millennium, or whatever, 
> then we all either have to relearn or we have to accept that we are becoming 
> the ever more perfect members of an ever decreasing herd.  That is perhaps a 
> fine thing if the objective is perfection of a hobby - it is a horrible thing 
> if the intent is to communicate with a larger and larger sphere of people.
> 
> Constant change is even more difficult if we intend to ever publish a body of 
> literature in Glosa, in my mind an absolute requirement for growth in the 
> number of users.  I asked this question earlier, and someone noted that they 
> could read something that had been written in Glosa years before.  That is 
> the cost of the language being stable - and whether or not you like Wendy 
> "owning" the language, that is the very great benefit of it.  If Glosa is 
> going to change routinely there is no reason for me, or any other author, to 
> write in it - half of the purpose of publishing books and articles is to 
> ensure the continuity of knowledge.  If 10 years from now people cannot read 
> what I have written because Glosa is Glosa 17, we will have missed the point. 
>   
> 
> I think debate about the future evolution of Glosa is a good thing.  I think 
> arguing about how best to express grammatical forms is wonderful.  But I 
> wonder why I do not see debate about how best to structure courses in basic 
> Glosa, what the content for an equivalent to the 10 lesson Esperanto course 
> should be and how to recruit tutors to deliver it, about how to develop and 
> encourage more publications in Glosa, about how to recognize Glosa 
> proficiency - in short about how to grow the community of users so that we 
> will have enough people to make all the inward looking arguments worthwhile 
> and significant?
> 
> I have proposed a Glosa introductory course for my University's Continuing 
> Professional Development and Personnel Enrichment Program (our continuing 
> education unit community outreach program).  We may even look at doing it 
> online.  So who has a good idea about what I should teach and how to get 
> students into the program?
> 
> And has anyone ever wondered why we use an emblem that is a marketing and 
> logo design nightmare to sell our language?  At least the Esperantists have a 
> simple green star ... and an easily recognizable flag ...
>

At 09:58 AM 11/7/02 EST, Walter (NOPSB) grafo:
>Dear Colleagues,
>
>I am a new Glosa user, and I am not a linguist or language builder - I
have far too much trouble writing well in English to consider myself other
than an imperfect  language user.  As a result, I think I have a different
perspective on Glosa from some of the discussion on the list.  
>
*  Hi All,
   Walter's is a fresh perspective.
   And, for me, the more perspective from which Glosa is viewed, the better.
   BTW, Walter from which culture/language_base do you come; you are doing
a lot better with English than many of those who have had the benefit of it
throughout their entire education.

>For me it does not matter whether Glosa is perfect or fine tuned if no one
uses it.  We have some discussion on this list in Glosa, we have a
newsletter from time to time, and not much more. 
*  This is a legitimate criticism.  There ought to be much more reporting
of items written in Glosa; and I am pleased to see, of late, that Marcel
has been able to add a Glosa version of St Mark's gospel and a
Glosa_original Science Fiction story to his website!
   This is, I'd say, the cutting edge of Glosa.
   I have invited people to write more children's stories in Glosa, but
have had no takers yet; I will have to dust off the children's stories and
start adding titles, myself.  Needless to say, I ought to update (edit) the
original three on my website.

>    If I wrote a book in Glosa (or if any 
>other member of this list did so), who would buy and read it?  Glosa
poorly constructed but used is far more relevant than Glosa perfectly
constructed and unused.  
>
*  At present, very few would know of its existence, and even fewer would
have had the Glosa training to be able to read it with full understanding,
BUT, many would, without any prior training in Glosa, be able to get the
general understanding of it from their knowlege of the Classical languages,
and from the consistency of the ^plain vanilla^ syntax within the writing.
    [I have invented  ^ ..... ^  to indicate metaphoric or idiomatic usage:
the general term to describe such usage is 'non-literal language'; all
languages use this sort of thing, and there should be a mechanism whereby
it can be used in Glosa, also.]

>If I am going to go to the trouble of learning and using a language I want
it to be stable.  The rules of French grammar or Spanish grammar do not
change every month - but if Glosa had followed all of the excursions I have
seen on this list, our change rate would be at least once a month.  
*  Two comments; while teaching in England, I met a teacher of French, who
felt it necessary to visit Paris at least every six months, to keep his
usage current, and to ensure that what he was teaching was up to date;
Glosa - in its usage and vocabulary - was basicaly "set" in 1992, with the
publication of the _Glosa 6000_ dictionary.

>      If I learn Glosa, 
>or Glosa 2, or whatever it is we are using, and the handful of people on
the list decide that they want to use Glosa 3, or New Millennium, or
whatever, then we all either have to relearn or we have to accept that we
are becoming the ever more perfect members of an ever decreasing herd.
That is perhaps a fine thing if the objective is perfection of a hobby - it
is a horrible thing if the intent is to communicate with a larger and
larger sphere of people.
>
*  Quite so.
   The piece I wrote in respose to the mention of numbers .. and my
invention of the distinguishing name 'New Millenium Glosa' .. was to
criticise such a trend towards schism, and to introduce the analogy of
computer games, which are always coming out with new versions - something
to be avoided in a Planned Language.

>Constant change is even more difficult if we intend to ever publish a body
of literature in Glosa, in my mind an absolute requirement for growth in
the number of users. 
*  The phrase "set in cement" keeps cropping up in my mind, and I keep
trying to suppress it.
   However, 'linguistic drift' does occur in all languages, and Glosa will
be no different; but, a language proposed to standardise global
intercommunication will need - after its worldwide adoption - some form of
regulatory control.  In a similar way to the method the French use - having
an official body that rules on usage - Glosa, if it is installed as the
International Auxilliary Language, will also need some degree of regulation.

>    I asked this question earlier, and someone noted that they 
>could read something that had been written in Glosa years before.  
*  This is basically true - othewise I could not get away with leaving the
children's stories, written in the early nineties, on my website.
   The basic criteria for Glosa have not changed from its inception, though
there has been some tweaking, such as the addition of a mechanism for using
"Passive Voice".  
   Ron Clark's dictum, "a word is modified by its precedent," is still
true, but the trick is in the interpretation of this 'rule'; and, the
'syntax-based grammar' under which Glosa operates, is derived from this
original dictum.

>    That is 
>the cost of the language being stable - and whether or not you like Wendy
"owning" the language, that is the very great benefit of it.
*  Were Wendy to demonstrate the power of her "ownership," and make
authoritative rulings on the usage and forward direction of Glosa, I would
probaly feel a little less unasy: her status in the Glosa heirarchy is
reminiscent of that of the Queen in Australia's.  The Queen is titular head
(and owner) of Australia, but plays no part in the running of the place.
   If Wendy was answering your comments, now, she would be seen to be
exerting the rights of an "owner."  The fact that she is not on the Net,
and that life, in general, makes it difficult for her to participate in the
day-to-day running of Glosa, suggests the need for something like an
Esperanto-style "academy" to watch over the development of the language.

>    If Glosa is 
>going to change routinely there is no reason for me, or any other author,
to write in it - half of the purpose of publishing books and articles is to
ensure the continuity of knowledge.  If 10 years from now people cannot
read what I have written because Glosa is Glosa 17, we will have missed the
point. 
>
*  When I fist met Ron Clark in 1977, the "Glossa" effort was definitely on
the "R" of its R&D; now we are much more into the "D" end of Glosa's R&D
spectrum, but not ^out of the woods^ of Research and Development altogether.
   Some see the need for a rock-solid lexicon as the necessary foundation
stone for the language.  I believe that Glosa-pe should be advancing on all
fronts; and, using the language within various genres is definitely part of
this "Development" phase - or, as we now say, 'Beta-testing.'  Does it work
effectively to convey all manner of information?  I "tested" Glosa, in the
early stages, on children's stories, to check out Glosa's effectiveness in
the 'affective' area: could I get across the feeling behind Cinderella's
mother's admonition that her daughter NOT venture into the woods; could I
convey the bears' desolation when their little visitor fled from them; how
heartbroken was Little Bear when he found his chair broken?
   So, is Glosa still a 'work in progress'?
   To some extent, I fear so.
   But, what is written in Glosa, to-day, will be quite clearly understood
by Glosa speakers of twenty years hence - though considered  a little
quaint, I suspect.
   
>I think debate about the future evolution of Glosa is a good thing.  I
think arguing about how best to express grammatical forms is wonderful.
But I wonder why I do not see debate about how best to structure courses in
basic Glosa, what the content for an equivalent to the 10 lesson Esperanto
course should be and how to recruit tutors to deliver it, about how to
develop and encourage more publications in Glosa, about how to recognize
Glosa proficiency - in short about how to grow the community of users so
that we will have enough people to make all the inward looking arguments
worthwhile and significant?
>
*  These questions definitely ^hit the nail on the head^ ... or on the thumb.
   The suggestion is that training and accreditation methods be developed;
the criticism is that they are not.
   We could do a lot worse than go through the historical _Step by Step in
Esperanto_ by Montagu C. Butler, and produce a Glosa version of it.  Such a
product would look something like a half-century later's update of Hogben's
_Interglossa_.
   Now that we are solidly into the electronic phase of our civilisation's
development, I feel that something that could come out with colour
illustrations, possibly with some "Flash" animations - and with the
benefits of hypertext links - might be made available on CD.
   This is not to say that hardcopy versions of Glosa instruction,
preferably in colour, but even some in stark B&W, would not do the job.
[BTW I have never used a double negative in Glosa; I wonder if it works?]
[[I saw a COLOUR lazer printer advertised in a computer magazine,
yesterday; I did not look at the price - but I could.]]
   While Ron Clark's _18 Steps to Fluency in Glosa_ is GEO copyrighted, and
is of extreme historical significance, it is far from the last word in
pedogological science.  With suitable will, we can do a lot better; and,
with a training plan, we could do even better, still.

>I have proposed a Glosa introductory course for my University's Continuing
Professional Development and Personnel Enrichment Program (our continuing
education unit community outreach program).  We may even look at doing it
online.  So who has a good idea about what I should teach and how to get
students into the program?
>
*  There are almost too many good questions, here; but, Walter, you are to
be congratulated for asking them all.
   Every good language course has a curriculum: I even suspect that
Esperanto has one.  By looking at the list of educational objectives in
such a curriculum, you should find a suitable list of Glosa learning
outcomes.  
   Would all members of the List please hunt through their archives, or
consult their local education authorities, so we can pool our information
on the Glosalist - and thus derive a suitable Glosa curriculum for Walter.

   In terms of the gearing of a 'continuing education' course in Glosa, I
am not sure who the advertising should be aimed at.  We cannot say that
Glosa is the successor to Esperanto: this is not currently a fact.  Printed
(or computer referenced) information on a "Learning Vocabulary", Glosa's
Rules of Grammar, and sectional vocabularies would probably be the place to
start.  But also, models of well-formed Glosa sentences, with explanatory
information, plus easy-reading examples of Glosa prose, would also be very
worthwhile.
   But this all begs the question of Course design.
   I'd go for action, and possibly excitement, every time.  We need to stir
the verbs - and stir the blood, in the same process.
   While 'the cat sitting on the mat' is passe, and somewhat boring, >cats
being chased by yelping dogs< gets some movement into the verbs, and allows
for delicious adjectives that get the emotions going.
   While most courses start with the somewhat passive tourist ogling
railway stations, busses and places of interest, I feel that Glosa-pe and
'citicens of the World' want a bit more action.  Perhaps a traffic scene,
with near misses, bustling pedestrians and shouting cops, would get
learners straight into 'thinking in Glosa' rather than treating the
learning of Glosa as a translation exercise.
   However, that being said, a study of the demographics of those wising to
take on 'further education' might turn up a wide range of motivations.
Some would respond to the challenge of learning a different language,
others might appreciate the possibility of acquiring the future global
second language, and some could see the connection between a language with
syntax-based grammar and the demands of computer Meta-languages.  There are
a number of good reasons for learning Glosa, not the least of which is that
most Glosa-pe are altruists.  However, I would add that the Internet, as a
global means of communication is, as yet, incomplete: the wires are twisted
together; the carrier software is installed; but the 'pinkware' through
which minds inter-communicate is still absent, and the "language problem"
has only been expressed at a higher level.
   So, what is the missing link in Global communication?  The language that
all can use and understand .. easily!
   To me the prime question is: why is a sentence?
   The answer for me is that we relate to one another by telling stories,
and the smallest components of these stories are sentences.
   Thus each sentence is a small story, with actors, victims and actions,
or Actor-Action-Victim .. and usually told in that order (S-V-O).  So, I'd
imagine an instructional schema that helped people build up sentences,
starting with small, uncomplicated ones, and building via the
sophistication of more complex phrases, up to the use of fully formed
clauses within sentences.  This pedogological aim would, of course, be
interwoven with the cultural, thematic material.  Hence the idea of
starting with an aspect of life that is almost automatic, and capable of
being dealt with in short sentences, like walking in traffic.  Actual
shopping, for example, requires a higher level of language, with
interaction between the buyer and the shop-keeper - hence it would come
later in the course.
   Because Glosa does not represent an existing culture, we can not assume
that people will automatically start thinking in Glosa; and, because Glosa
does not concretely see words as distinct parts of speech, nor does it have
the facilitation of "inflections", the learner is left to juggle the raw
concepts as ideational words.  This is an acquirable trick, but it can also
be a bit of a shock to people brought up in the learning-by-hearing
tradition.  Here I have to mention creativity: the more imagination a
person has, then the faster they will catch onto Glosa's founding formula.

   Of course, we don't tell people this is also the problem with English,
and the minimal degree of inflection (~5) allows people to think of English
as a normal sort of European language.  But it is not: English is a
'bastard' language comprising two different grammatical systems, one of
which is 'syntax-based.'
   So, Glosa does what English has been tending to do - dropping out the
inflections - but carries this trend on to its logical conclusion.
     EG  the English cricket team  -->  the England cricket team

>And has anyone ever wondered why we use an emblem that is a marketing and
logo design nightmare to sell our language?  At least the Esperantists have
a simple green star ... and an easily recognizable flag ...
>
*  Good question.  I didn't wonder: I knew.  Ron Clark chose the Greek
letter "Psi" to symbolise the idea behind Glosa.  He doubled the circular
bit to say there is an inner and an outer level of Glosa usage.  The outer
represents the more pedestrian use of language, while the inner circle
represents more rigorous usage - within science, law and business.

           /           \
          |  /       \  |
          |  |   |   |  |
           \  \__|__/  /
            \____|____/ 
                 |
                 |
                 |

   Agreed, it doesn not translate readily into the popular culture, nor
onto flag or in email.  So, an extra - more popularly recognisable - symbol
might be needed.

   With apologies about the length of this post, I look forward to working
with the group that supports Walter in his aims.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

At 02:25 PM 10/23/02 +0200, you wrote:
>Karo Robin
>Mi pa lekto tu grama e me gratia tu de id.
>Mi efekti analizi u struktura de plura lingua e mi pa face
>u kompara ko Glosa. .....
*  Karo Mico e plu amika,
   Mi pa lekto u grama ex Mico ko facili.
   An ne uti plu excesi forma ex England-lingua, sed mi plu oku pa kursi
epi an verbi, e logi u semani.  Mi kredi ke an gene sko de plu hetero
lingua, bi natura e ge-face, duce an te detekti un ideo qalita de Glosa, e
te uti u-ci lingua iso u puri forma.
   Koncerne plu lingua grupa intra Eoropa, mi ski ke na habe plu
Germani/Teutoni grega pluso plu lingua ge-crea ex plu Klasiko lingua.
   Tem maxi-pe kogita de plu Latino ge-basi lingua, Span., Italia, Portug.,
iso ge forma seqe Romani vikto, na nece dice ke bi plu Klasiko lingua gene
ge-uti intra skience, sed pluso intra England- lingua e Ruso-lingua.
   Ron Clark pa decide de uti plu lingua, ex qi na gene u terminologi de
skience, iso an fonta pro Glosa.  An tende uti u maxi uti-ple forma, ex alo
Greko alo Latino, te kompile u lexiko pro Glosa.  Pro poesi, an freqe pa
inklude mo verbi, ge-prende ex singo lingua, EG aqa e hidro.  An regula pa
es ke bi Greko e Latino forma habe gru in Glosa, si na habe brevi e kausa
nuli disputa ko plu verbi-litera de plu hetero verbi.
   U-ci dikta, ex Ron, pa du kausa poli problema, ka u numera de plu
Glosa-uti-pe vo habe solo mo verbi pro singo koncepa.  Basi, u Glosa 1000
verbi-lista habe no-sufici koncepa, tem u Glosa 6000 diktionari tena excesi
simi-nima.  Si id pa habe solo bi versio pre singo koncepa, na posi uti id
ko facili; sed, ko poli kaso, u koncepa pa habe tetra, alo ma, simi-nima.
   Seqe-co, plura de na pa decide ke u vokabulari ko 2500 - 3000 verbi sio
posi dona sati a plu neo gene-sko-pe.  U tali verbi-bibli pote permito u
pusi numera de plu importa simi-nima.

   Durante mi recento no-ergo-tem, mi pa skema de krea u tali lista, sed id
ne acide.  Nu, ko Walter expresi plu dificili qestio, iso ~qod na akti te
auxi plu gene-sko-pe~, mi kredi ke u tem nu ariva pro u poduce de u-ci
'Sko-pe Vokabulari".

   Te auxi mi ko u-ci ergo, mi vo gene, ex plu membra de u Lista, plu
refere a plura ge-publiko brevi lista de verbi/koncepa pro plu sko-pe - ko
u 2000-3000 verbi numera.

Gracia,

At 03:51 PM 11/8/02 EST, Sid wrote:
>agree about the capitals and wrote as much some time ago - i tend to leave 
>them out in glosa, some europeanophiles are not happy but hindi for instance 
>does without them happily. i am working on the assumption that the glosa
rule 
>is no caps but they can be used if required and in any way that people  want
>i did toy with making a sort of tutorial whereby there was a story and each 
>sentence's grammar, vocab etc was explained. however the attitude to grammar 
>was rather confused
>   .....
*    Hello Sid and All,
     While Sid sees capitals, and, I suspect, fullstops, as optional extras
in Glosa, I do not.
     Firstly, hindi users of Glosa - I have not met any yet - might choose
to optionally avoid the use of capital letters and most punctuation, but
the downside of this could be that many Glosa-pe will not attempt to read
what they have written.
     Secondly, with a syntax-based grammar system, I feel that Glosa needs
all the legitimate help it can get.  In fact, it is my considered belief
that punctuation is a part of Glosa grammar, acting as sign-posts to the
start and finish of the various elements of sentences.
     Thirdly, Capitals have to main functions, in Glosa, as I see it: they
denote the start of a new sentence; and they indicate the presence of a
proper noun - a particular person or place.
      mi fe-fili gina pa dice qestio qe id du pluvi     .......... (1)
  OR
      Mi fe-fili, Gina, pa dice qestio, ~Qe, id du pluvi?~.   .... (2)

    I suspect that each of thes sentences could be marked, with points
accumulating for ambiguity/lack_of_clarity, and I feel that the former
version would show a greater mandicap rating than the latter.
    While the writer of 1. would know where to pause, and where to put
vocal stress, when he read it out, someone else handed the message might
have to think for a while before he could understand the message - as he
thought the writer intended it.
    Someone reading 2. as an 'unseen', on the other hand, has twelve
additional cues to the structure, semantics and unusual components of the
sentence, and could read it with suitable pauses and vocal stress,
directly, by making use of these non-alphanumeric clues.

    Sid, I, for one, find the reading of your posts difficult, because of
the lack of signposts to their structure.

    If you are conducting an experiment, what is its hypothesis, how do you
test it, and when do you know that the hypotesis has been disproved?

    Fashions in language come and go, and some just keep coming.  At
present, the smart young things are leaving out increasing numbers of
commas from their writing.
    I predict that there will ultimately be a swing against this trend ..
when grammar is again taught in our schools.  I am not sure how many
generations will get lost in the wilderness of stream_of_consciousness-type
writing before the cry goes up - for greater clarity in the structure of
prose; things could get a lot worse, before they start getting better.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

*   Maybe so.
    But, I know Ron had the capacity to work at Genius level, and I also
know that I do not.  So, I fear that further years spent in trying to
derive a different formulation, based on present Glosa, and forming a
superior language from it - much as Ron derived Glosa from Interglossa -
would end with me dead, as well, also not seeing the full fruition of the
new form I had created.

    I see my role more as a Beta Tester of Glosa, and not as that of a
co-creator of the world's best 'syntax-based' language.  During the time
that I was Alpha Testing Glossa/Glosa (1982 - 1992) I had a pretty bumpy
ride.  Since entering the Beta Testing phase, I have felt much happier,
there having been many fewer changes.

    Personally, I have not enough room in my life, nor years up my sleeve,
to go through a phase of Alpha Testing, again.  And, if we look at the
progress made, up til now, on the Glosalist, we could predict a very slow
speed of progress, if people were asked to go back to basics, and start
again, with some New Millenium Glosa.
    Ron Clark, after working with Interglossa for about four year, did,
around 1976, clear the slate, and start again - with a revision and
simplification of  Hogben's "outline" of an auxillary language.

    However, it does test my imagination .. to the limit .. to try to push
the basic framework of Glosa(Clark/Ashby, 1992) into a better shape than it
is already.  Agreed, the refinements of vocabulary are calling, and a
clear, simple statement of Glosa's grammar would help, but these are
peripheral to the language's specification, which seems pretty damned good.

    My guess, is, that with urging from Walter and Carmelo, Glosa is due to
take a step forward, not backwards, into Gamma testing.  I welcome this,
and will do my best to trim around the edges, of any ragged pieces
remaining from the Beta Testing phase.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

At 02:01 AM 11/8/02 +0000, Tom Croft wrote:
>I'm very new to glosa---I like what (little) I know of the langauge,
>but a few things occurred to me (unstructured babble commences):
>
>If the goal is to skim internationality from common languages,
>surely `helo' is a better greeting than `ave'..?  Ave gets the piss
>taken out of it in Asterix IIRC (which I do, a small point, I know)
>
*  Tom your comments and observations are vey welcome, but you might guess
that you come in .. at what I am now calling the Gamma Testing phase.
   One of the original authors is dead, and the second is not as active as
we might have hoped: non-Net and arthritic.

   Sorry about Asterix, but you can start your letters "Karo Fred" and end
them with a non-comicbook, "Saluta."
   Actually, for thousands of years, "Ave!" was more of a farewell. 
   To address "Friends" using Glosa, you might find ~Mi Plu Amika,~ more to
your liking.

   No Glosa is not actually a 'skim' of the worlds languages; it is much
more a "language for science - that can be spoken by the common man, as well."
   And here's a neat concept: recall the teaching of Scientific French and
Scientific Russian, etc; now, imagine that instead of Russian or French
joining words between the scientific terminology, you stick "glue words"
from the same (Greko-Latin) source as the terminology;  you end up with
something that can be called Scientific Scientific.

   Needless to say such a streamlined, simplified language needs a grammar:
Ron Clark, the prime author chose the logical structure of English sentence
construction, but got rid of the five inflections in English, and created a
grammar which is 'syntax-based.'  Recall how computer programming languages
always go on about their syntax - but never about their 'inflections.'  He
thought the language was so simple, obvious and logical that he avoided
publishing a Glosa Grammar: he said the mind sorted it out intuitively; it
is possible that, in this, he over-estimated human capabilities.

>Artificial language `lojban' dispenses with uppercase letters (a
>most elegant move!), and while glosa is targetted at europeans I
>presume (who are already aquainted with uppercase and such), that
>would be a good change to the language in my humble, uneducated,
>opinion.
>
*  Just because Glosa uses the plain Euro alphabet, you might imagine that
it is Euro-based.  However consider for a moment, a World auxilliary
language will have to use a single form of graphical representation: what
is you preference?
   Did you know that the Chinese see their language as a potential global
auxilliary with all of its umpteen thousands of characters.

   BTW in your studies of lojban did you find it to be a very precise,
rule-based proscriptive language?  Well human beings don't work like that:
our biological logic circuits are much more fuzzy and imprecise.
   Although I perhaps should not say it, because even the great Chomsky
could not spell it out, Glosa was designed to mirror the 'Universal
Language of Thought.'  Please consider: perhaps Clark, using creativity,
intuited something that Chomsky, with all of his intelligence, did not.

>I agree that major changes are probably undesirable; if any are to be
>made, they must be made before the tutorials are written ;-).  
*  Some tutes do exist already. Seminars #1 & #2 are on my website, and are
just as relevant to-day, as they were when I wrote them at least five years
ago.
   An easy to follow statement of the grammar is in the process of being
developed, and a course suitable for 'Further Education' is being mooted by
Walter.

>Language does of course change (Marlowe can be great, but he's fucking
impossible to read in any original form without translating
>constantly), but yes, I agree the literature of last decade must
>remain comprehensible!
>
*  I suggest that global civilisation is just around the corner, and it
could be a good thing; but, if we are to make it work for the best,  it
will need a humanly usable auxilliary language.  The Star Trek time scale
possibly is just beginning.

>The glosa symbol I also thought ridiculous.  How about a red triangle?
It's easy, and it can be asciified thusly: [/\]  
>
*  Perhaps we should call in the graphic designers.
   I note that triangles are getting a bad press from the No-NWO people.
And for this reason, I would like to steer clear of triangles, even though
the idea of a "Global Language" could be part of some NWO agenda.

>2: It's a piece of piss to read with a dictionary programme; I learnt

to town' etc.  This was much easier than the intellectual effort

    I always thought that Ron said h'ed written the specification so that
Glosa would be emminently suitable for the machine handling of information.

>On a more negative note, I was put off considerably by the connection
>to latin.  That word evokes fear in people!  I would suggest replacing it
with "common european word roots" wherever possible!
>
*  Sorry about the irrational fear.
   Most of the early terms from science are derived from Latin; though,
now, Greek is proving more useful.
   The original word stem is called Indo-European: both Greek and Latin
come from this; and I simplify the phrase "Greek and Latin roots" to saying
"the Classical roots of science."

>I never used the esperanto interactive tutorials (OK, so I did, but

I've generated a vocabulary of 6730 words from several
international public-domain sources, including the
combined Glosa list, Ido/Novial, the Romance languages,
and a few others. The algorithm is impartial and
reproducible, and capable of improvement and updating.

All words conform to the easily-pronounced bisyllabic
consonant-vowel pattern, resembling the "scientific
combining forms" in ease of compounding, yet still
remain somewhat recognizable or at least plausible
at-first-sight to Romance speakers.

While not "perfect" or "final", this appears much
more attractive and practical than the current
Glosa vocabulary. I think it would be a good basis
for the necessary Glosa reforms. It is even possible
to write tolerable pidginesque text by using it
experimentally without any grammatical particles.

If anyone here is interested. In the last world-war
most interest in IALs died; looks like a repeat now.

Robin asks me if I am experimenting, yes, and investigating too. I have been

if I had not thought highly of G, I would have left it long ago, however, I 
think that like everything else in the world, there are shortcomings and it 
is these that I am looking at. also I was in touch with hindi and similar 
languages while i was teaching and helping boys from southern asia.
my views on full stops seem to be misunderstood rather. If I were 
[hand]writing in G or any other language with the roman alphabet and could 
keep my writing legible, i would make the dot at the end of a sentence 
largish and slightly far away from the last letter. no problems in seeing it 
and it works perfectly adequately.
however in some type fonts the dot is tiny and put next to the last 'd'. as 
far as i am concerned the dot is invisible and looks like part of the 
squiggly bit at the end of the letter [serif]. i just can't see it! This 
seems to have been noticed long, long ago. Instead of doing something about 
the dot, it has been decide to make the following letter a capital. now we 
have to learn 52 letters instead of 26 and we have the end doubly and 
redundantly marked!

Subject: Re: [glosalist] An attempt to write in glosa, prior to learning it
